The Towson Inn was a famous colonial hostelry.

T)wson’s heritage dates back to the year
1750 when two Englishmen by the name of
Towson, one accompanied by his wife,
crossed the Atlantic to the new world. On
arriving in America, they traveled southward
looking for an ideal place to settle. Eventually
they camped on a beautiful ridge about nine
miles from Baltimore Town. There, they
overlooked three beautiful valleys; there were
sparkling springs of pure water; the land was
fertile, and wild game was plentiful.

Deciding that this, indeed, was the ideal
place for them to settle, they built a log cabin
at a spot which would now be on Joppa Road,
a short distance west of York Road. The
beauty and abundance of the location at-
tracted other settlers, and soon there was a
village of twenty homes in the area.

By 1768, the Towsons perceived that the
erection of an inn to accommodate travelers
going to and from Baltimore could be a good
investment. Accordingly, they built in that
year The Towson Inn, which became famous
for its fine food and accommodations and
continued to be a center of Towson activity
until it was torn down in 1929. It was a
three-story stone building, and many famous
figures of our country’s early history stopped
there.

A son of the founding family who brought
fame to the town as the result of his military
accomplishments was Nathan Towson, who
was born in 1754, just four years after his
father had started the Towson settlement.
Reaching young manhood, he entered the
Colonial Army, served with valor and dis-
tinction throughout the Revolutionary War
and rose to the rank of General.

He returned to Towson in 1805 and engaged
in farming until the War of 1812 broke out.
He then returned to the Army and had signal
success in the defense of Fort Erie and the
Battle of Chippewa.

Towson became the County Seat of Balti-
more County in 1854; and, in that year, the
cornerstone was laid for the Court House.

Subsequent additions have greatly enlarged
the Court House, but the original building
can be readily identified by the darker,
brownish-colored stone used in its construc-
tion.

Being the center of legal activity in the
county, Towson grew steadily. It also as-
sumed an industrial flavor. Charles Ridgely,
of Hampton, had expanded the iron works at
North Hampton. Of course, Towsontown, as
it was then known, was a center of shopping
and business activity for a fertile and highly
productive farming area.

Following World War I and the advent of
automobiles, further growth was stimulated.
In the interval between two World Wars,
Harry T. Campbell Sons’ Corporation, Black
& Decker and Bendix Radio were just a few
of the leading firms to prosper in the area,
creating employment and spurring economic
growth.

Then, following World War II the Greater
Towson Area’s period of fastest growth
began.

New homes sprang up in attractive develop-
ments, new businesses moved into the area
and many desirable light industrial plants
were constructed.

Today, the Towson area—with its many fine
schools and colleges, its beautiful residential
areas, its splendid industries and its cultural
and recreational advantages — is one of the
fastest-growing, most prosperous areas in the
United States.



Timonium House gave the town its name.

'I;le town of Timonium derived its name
from a home—a home that, like the town

itself, is rich in tradition.

The home, located on Timonium Road just
west of York Road, was originally called
Belle Field; and it was built in the early
1700’s by Dr. George Buchanan, who came
to this country from Scotland and became a
leading figure in the area. He was among the
first commissioners of Baltimore Town.

Archibald Buchanan inherited Belle Field
from his father. Archibald married Sarah
Brooks Lee, sister of Maryland Governor
Thomas Sim Lee; and the couple entertained
many famous figures of the day at their home.

Then, in 1785, following the death of Archi-
bald Buchanan, Mrs. Buchanan visited her
close friend, Cassandra Dyer Owings Van
Paradelles in New Orleans. The two decided
to return to Maryland but did not sail
together.

Mrs. Buchanan reached Baltimore safely, but
Mrs. Van Paradelles was never heard from,
and her death was feared. Years later, when
Dominick—the chief pirate of Lafitte—lay on
his death bed, he told a clergyman about forc-
ing a Maryland lady to walk the plank and
was able to produce her jewelry, which was
identified as Mrs. Van Paradelles’. Mrs.
Buchanan likened her grief over the loss of
her close friend to that of Timon of Athens
and renamed Belle Field “Timonium”,
which means “Veil of Tears”. The town of
Timonium, of course, derived its name from
this historic home.

In 1830, a one-mile horse racing track—the
first mile track in Maryland—was constructed
on the original property of Timonium House.
The track was abandoned in 1840, when the
Baltimore-Susquehanna Railroad ran its
track through the center of the race course.
Later, in 1878, the first Timonium Fair was
held at the present location. In 1879, live-
stock, farm and manufactured products were
displayed, and trotting and speed races were
held on each of the four days during which
the fair was in operation.

The Timonium Fair has been held continu-
ously since that time, except during World
War 1I, when the Army used the grounds as
a storage and repair depot.

Since the end of World War II, Timonium
has flowered as a desirable residential area.
Shopping centers have sprung up, and it has
become a center for light industrial activity
with many modern plants housing nationally
known companies being located there.

The Sherwood Episcopal Church
was built in 1835.



Cockeysvill’e, which derived its name from
the family that settled the section in the early
Eighteenth Century, developed as a trading
center for a rich agricultural area.

However, shortly after the Revolutionary
War fine marble and limestone deposits were
discovered nearby. The stone was ground and
dried in kilns for use as a flux and as fer-
tilizer. Cockeysville Marble became famous
and was used for building and decorative pur-
poses (including Baltimore’s famous white
marble steps). Also, the building of the Wash-
ington Monument and many governmental
buildings in the Nation’s Capitol kept pro-
duction humming and stimulated Cockeys-
ville’s economy.

Iron, too, was prominent in Cockeysville’s
economy during the 1800’s. The ore was
mined in the area and reduced to metal in
furnaces at Ashland and Oregon. Also, Cock-
eysville’s industry of the day included a rye
whiskey distillery and cotton mills.

The Sherwood Episcopal church, built in
1835, and the Cockeysville Tavern, construc-
ed in 1810, still stand in the town.

Quarrying and allied operations have contin-
ued to be a major phase of Cockeysville’s
economy over the years, as Harry T. Camp-
bell Sons’ Corporation operates one of the
largest open pit operations in the east and
supplies many products for construction and
for industry.

During the 1920’s, members of the William-
son family started a veneer mill in Cockeys-
ville which, with subsequent construction of
additional plants by other members of the
family, has become a major industry in the
area.

More recently, companies producing items
for national defense and in the missile/space
field, steel products, precision metal parts,
wire and other items have become a part of
the Cockeysville scene.

Also, the development of the Greater Balti-
more Industrial Park in the area has attracted
new businesses and industries.

T)wson’s heritage dates back to the year

Subsequent additions have greatly enlarged
the Court House, but the original building
can be readily identified by the darker,
brownish-colored stone used in its construc-
tion.

Being the center of legal activity in the
county, Towson grew steadily. It also as-
sumed an industrial flavor. Charles Ridgely,
of Hampton, had expanded the iron works at
North Hampton. Of course, Towsontown, as
it was then known, was a center of shopping
and business activity for a fertile and highly
productive farming area.

Following World War I and the advent of
automobiles, further growth was stimulated.
In the interval between two World Wars,
Harry T. Campbell Sons’ Corporation, Black
& Decker and Bendix Radio were just a few
of the leading firms to prosper in the area,
creating employment and spurring economic
growth.

Then, following World War II the Greater
Towson Area’s period of fastest growth
began.

New homes sprang up in attractive develop-
ments, new businesses moved into the area
and many desirable light industrial plants
were constructed.

Today, the Towson area—with its many fine
schools and colleges, its beautiful residential
areas, its splendid industries and its cultural
and recreational advantages — is one of the
fastest-growing, most prosperous areas in the
United States.



Timonium House gave the town its name.

'I;le town of Timonium derived its name
from a home—a home that, like the town

itself, is rich in tradition.

The home, located on Timonium Road just
west of York Road, was originally called
Belle Field; and it was built in the early
1700’s by Dr. George Buchanan, who came
to this country from Scotland and became a
leading figure in the area. He was among the
first commissioners of Baltimore Town.

Archibald Buchanan inherited Belle Field
from his father. Archibald married Sarah
Brooks Lee, sister of Maryland Governor
Thomas Sim Lee; and the couple entertained
many famous figures of the day at their home.

Then, in 1785, following the death of Archi-
bald Buchanan, Mrs. Buchanan visited her
close friend, Cassandra Dyer Owings Van
Paradelles in New Orleans. The two decided
to return to Maryland but did not sail
together.

Mrs. Buchanan reached Baltimore safely, but
Mrs. Van Paradelles was never heard from,
and her death was feared. Years later, when
Dominick—the chief pirate of Lafitte—lay on
his death bed, he told a clergyman about forc-
ing a Maryland lady to walk the plank and
was able to produce her jewelry, which was
identified as Mrs. Van Paradelles’. Mrs.
Buchanan likened her grief over the loss of
her close friend to that of Timon of Athens
and renamed Belle Field “Timonium”,
which means “Veil of Tears”. The town of
Timonium, of course, derived its name from
this historic home.

In 1830, a one-mile horse racing track—the
first mile track in Maryland—was constructed
on the original property of Timonium House.
The track was abandoned in 1840, when the
Baltimore-Susquehanna Railroad ran its
track through the center of the race course.
Later, in 1878, the first Timonium Fair was
held at the present location. In 1879, live-
stock, farm and manufactured products were
displayed, and trotting and speed races were
held on each of the four days during which
the fair was in operation.

The Timonium Fair has been held continu-
ously since that time, except during World
War 1I, when the Army used the grounds as
a storage and repair depot.

Since the end of World War II, Timonium
has flowered as a desirable residential area.
Shopping centers have sprung up, and it has
become a center for light industrial activity
with many modern plants housing nationally
known companies being located there.

The Sherwood Episcopal Church
was built in 1835.



Cockeysvill’e, which derived its name from
the family that settled the section in the early
Eighteenth Century, developed as a trading
center for a rich agricultural area.

However, shortly after the Revolutionary
War fine marble and limestone deposits were
discovered nearby. The stone was ground and
dried in kilns for use as a flux and as fer-
tilizer. Cockeysville Marble became famous
and was used for building and decorative pur-
poses (including Baltimore’s famous white
marble steps). Also, the building of the Wash-
ington Monument and many governmental
buildings in the Nation’s Capitol kept pro-
duction humming and stimulated Cockeys-
ville’s economy.

Iron, too, was prominent in Cockeysville’s
economy during the 1800’s. The ore was
mined in the area and reduced to metal in
furnaces at Ashland and Oregon. Also, Cock-
eysville’s industry of the day included a rye
whiskey distillery and cotton mills.

The Sherwood Episcopal church, built in
1835, and the Cockeysville Tavern, construc-
ed in 1810, still stand in the town.

Quarrying and allied operations have contin-
ued to be a major phase of Cockeysville’s
economy over the years, as Harry T. Camp-
bell Sons’ Corporation operates one of the
largest open pit operations in the east and
supplies many products for construction and
for industry.

During the 1920’s, members of the William-
son family started a veneer mill in Cockeys-
ville which, with subsequent construction of
additional plants by other members of the
family, has become a major industry in the
area.

More recently, companies producing items
for national defense and in the missile/space
field, steel products, precision metal parts,
wire and other items have become a part of
the Cockeysville scene.

Also, the development of the Greater Balti-
more Industrial Park in the area has attracted
new businesses and industries.
